comments.commentBody: In the near hysteria (led by the Republican/Tea party right wing ideologues)to cut the national debt by 3-4 trillion dollars in the next decade there has been almost no mention of the fact that this figure is almost exactly the amount spent on our wars of choice in Iraq and Afghanistan. I am dismayed and disappointed that the poor and middle class are now being asked to foot the bill for these wars while the wealthiest citizens and corporations are using their influence to avoid paying their fair share of the national debt.
Tiger Woods demanding loyalty: now that's rich.

As several have already said here, Tiger Woods made Steve Williams a multi-millionaire. Now, we all know that being rich doesn't automatically confer graciousness and consideration. They pay other people to be gracious for them.

No doubt Woods could have handled this better, and OK, Williams is surprised and hurt, but he could just walk away saying "it was quite a ride and I thank Tiger very much for taking me along" - i.e., he could be a grownup about it. Instead he's letting his inner child loose to throw a tantrum, and that's just petty and mean. Making threats about "my book" just throws gas on the fire. And when (or if) people ever talk about Steve Williams again, they're going to remember this.

I sincerely hope that Wood's caddie is not coming forward with charges similar to those made by the many women of last year.

Wood's caddie was a loyal and trusted confidante to Mr. Tiger for many years and cut a dignified portrait on the fairways all these years.

It is beneath contempt for Wood's to cut this man off without a fair severance package or golden parachute.

Steve Williams might have trouble being picked up as a caddy by another leading golfer.  His website indicates a large persona that some might view as unwanted baggage on and off the course. Also, just about the worse thing he could have done is to mention his future book.

Not like I am a huge Tiger Woods fan--quite the opposite, in fact--but the article still doesn't answer a fundamental question (and one that I had after just reading the headline): did Woods have an employment contract with his caddy (it would seem to be de rigueur), and if so, did it have a severance package and/or non-disclosure clause?

I'm no gazillionaire sports figure, or even a lawyer (although my brother is), but it would seem to me that when hiring an employee that has such a personal connection with you, and not being part of a corporation with HR departments, the least Woods' manager/agent/whomever is supervising his hires should insist upon would be something to that effect.

It just seems like a no-brainer. I would do something like that (a non-disclosure agreement) automatically, and I lead a scandal-free life. If the likes of Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie have their employees sign such documents (which they do), one would assume that his lawyer would insist on such a clause to prevent this sort of blowback (much worse in this technological age than Nicklaus or Lopez) from occurring.

That said, I'm still enjoying a bit of Schadenfreude at Woods' expense, somewhat guiltily. And while it would be a little classier if his caddy had left during the moral turpitude phase, it would be nice to give a severance package for years of loyalty. It might have prevented this "tell all" from occurring to begin with.

Good, um, luck, Tiger.

Photographers who cover golf everywhere are laughing today. Williams is experiencing karma. This is just funny. Two very, very unsympathetic characters behaving badly. But how can Williams be surprised by his former employer's lack of class and humanity. He was Tiger's boy long enough to know the nature of the beast and how he treats people. As for Williams, good to see him get knocked down a few pegs.

This seems pretty simple.

If the caddie made millions, he should consider himself more than lucky and shut up. If he didn't, he should consider himself entitled to some sort of generous severence.

In Tiger's defense, he needs to make a change. Just like a bad marriage, he needs to move on to something different to regain his magic, if he can, and a new caddie is an obvious move.

Good luck to both men.

Williams is regarded as perhaps the best caddy of modern times. He was with Floyd and Norman before Woods. And yes he did argue with Woods on the course about which club to play many times. Its surprising that Williams didn't dump Woods, with all the trouble he had controlling his clubs when Williams wasn't around.

Woods is searching for a place where his wrongs are forgotten and Williams is part of the past.

The real test is whether Williams can perform the same magic with Adam Scott who has been a real underachiever over the last ten year now that he has become his caddy.

comments.userDisplayName: name with held for obvious reasons
comments.commentBody:
this man caddied for three of the best golfers ever and made a lot of money. cry us a river. he is the perfect example of why and who will be the first to lose everything when the powerless and oppressed rise up and take everything from those who have it all.

easy advice mr. williams: shut yer pie hole
Tiger has no friends.  He has many people who spend a lot of time close to him but he is a business, not a friend.  Williams made a ton of money - CEO money - for carrying a bag.  He'll be OK.

If, as some on this thread suggest, caddies are so dispensable, just “the help”, why are they paid so much?  I mean, if it's really just business, if they're really servants, then surely, anyone will do.  Seems to me, as a student of human nature, Woods is still looking to blame others for his character issues.  For his inability to be a successful golfer when he has to own all of his personality, warts and talent, not just the facade he and his slick handlers sold for billions of dollars of endorsements.  It seems hardly credible that Williams is Wood’s problem.  I think Woods is all swing and no follow through.  He’s in the rough and he’s slashing at the ball with the impotent rage of a man who still hasn’t recognized his own shallowness and vanity.
Who cares about Stevie? Tiger made him a millionaire for crying out loud. Take your money and laugh but don't expect pity from golfing fans. What a pathetic example of a huge ego.

I don't think either of them come off very well here.  Williams has reason to be disappointed, but he should keep it to himself and his friends, and move on.  Tiger proves he is the same arrogant, self-absorbed jerk he proved during his marriage. Of course he has the right to change caddies.  But can you do it with some class?  I always found it hard to like Tiger, but easy to admire him.  Now I find it hard to do that as well.

Steve, the caddie made more than probably three fourths the tour pros - and he is miffed!  Please!  You had a great run with the best golf player ever. Its over. Lower your level of lifestyle and you'll do just fine financially for a while

It's a travesty that America is ceding the future of space flight to other countries and, of course, to corporations. Private space flight is inevitable and, within legal limits yet to be defined, desireable. But with its emphasis on profit, it can never fully replace government and multinational programs in areas of pure research unlikely to produce immediate returns.

A fascinating article. But it will be interesting to see how far these plans get considering the paltry sums - a few tens of millions of dollars - so far raised. Would a Warren Buffett, or a Carl Icahn, or any hedge fund - all of them with billions at their disposal - invest in any of these projects? I don't think so. Business enterprise in the United States today only rarely goes in for very long term or very uncertain promises of profitability.

Consider this analogy: the internet was the result of decades of work by thousands of people in universities, and in defense and space programs, the vast majority of whom garnered only a paycheck and little fame.

It was not the result of "free enterprise," of course, but rather of many millions of dollars of government subvention in the interest of national prestige and national security. Even the corporate defense and space and other private contractors who may have profited in the early days of the internet or its progenitors like Arpanet were guaranteed that profit by the federal government.

All of that turned out eventually to be a kind of subsidy to the immense IT fortunes being made today by private corporations and individuals - fortunes impossible without the internet. Fortunes which draw directly upon taxpayer funded innovations in software, and electronic and other technologies which comprise the basis for the modern world wide web.

The same would apply to any successful so-called "private venture" to land on the Moon.

I attended Hunter back in the 70s, and they had a similar program.  We took our morning courses in an actual school and worked with teachers and students the rest of the day.  Nothing beats real-world experience.  That being said, I do not trust anything that is run by a "charter corporation".  You really have to understand your subject matter and find ways to communicate it that go beyond the textbook.  Unfortunately in this test-crazed society, teachers are no longer valued for being creative and getting results.

If I may make a suggestion; don't just fret over this, be prepared. Communicate with family to set up your own bailout plans like a place to live or help with the bills. I'm especially glad I have a Republican family member I can grub off to make him realize his party did this.
But seriously, don't be paralyzed by all this, prepare yourselves, and always remember; living in America during tough times is still far greater than being in many other countries. Everyone be prepared to help your fellow man.

Training has to be based upon evidence, no different than medical training.

But it also isn't just about training, it's about training the best and brightest. Pay teachers like doctors, and you can hand pick the talent and then train them in ways that empirically work. Instead, we offer up pathetic pay for super challenging conditions...and it should be no surprise that educational schools are predominantly comprised of the lowest scoring students (ones who could never carve out a career in engineering, business, medicine, law).

Don't get me wrong, there are some very big hearted and super talented and brilliant people choosing education despite the pay. Thank god for them. But they are far far too few.

I have a HUGE respect for the teaching profession. Its about time we invested in it and got the best of our population into this field.

Dumping Rosetta was nonsensical. Sure, it really motivates developers to update their apps, but it also forces a lot of users to pay for a large number of upgrades simultaneously.

Rosetta should have been allowed to continue on as a paid piece of software from Apple's very own App Store. It's a perfect platform to sell niche pieces of software that need to pay their own way after the market as a whole has moved on.

Thanks for pointing out that the new operating system shuts out various useful programs.  Office 2004, Quicken and Canvas are all workhorses for me and upgrading to a new system seems to me almost the same as the OS move from 10.3 to 10.4 which removed the ability to use Classic programs.  I still have an old iMac to run those.  I'll wait until Lion turns into Sabre-tooth with more of an incentive than a mail program before I convert.

Plan a healthy pregnancy with regular yoga practice and proper diet intake before, during and after pregnancy. Yoga provides relieve to all sorts of pain and helps in smoother delivery. Pregnancy and yoga is a perfect combination to start a family. Exercises for pregnancy differs with age and hence it is unique for each pregnant lady.
http://www.divinewellness.com/yoga/applications-of-yoga/yoga-for-women/y...

I went to Denver in 2008 believing that we would elect someone who would end the eight years of Bush's nightmare. We got someone who believe in nothing but selling out. Don't go on my leg and then tell me it's rain. I'm a black middle aged american. I will not vote in 2012, if he sells us out on social security and medicare. What is the difference between him and a republican?

I am of the baby boom generation, who did not live as financially high as my parents, though I went to college. Grandfathers had less education than my sons, who are in grad school. Yet my parents spoke of plentiful jobs after W.W. II, especially with a college degree. The 1950's were good times for them and into the 1960's. I read recently that if inflation were to keep up with what we had even in the mid 1970's, minimum wage should be $24/hr. So, let's face it...these are different times. Even though it would hurt my aging parents, and eventually my inheritance, I think they should raise taxes.  They should pay more taxes or some day, my sons, even with their  PhD's,and MD/PhD, and  MD in surgery, will not be able to repay school debt and begin careers. They are already working crazy long hours and struggling to begin paying off debt, deferring families, to get trained. They work and study so hard and it has been so difficult for them and for me, on a teacher's salary, to cover these expenses. So, raise taxes! It is only fair and will determine the future health of the country. I mean, how many houses and cars do these top 2% need?!
